Apple's AI efforts have resulted in a Google partnership, management changes, and two new versions of Siri. Apple is planning an announcement ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå  ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå ‚Äå 

Sign Up |Advertise|View Online
TLDR

Together With

TLDR 2026-01-26

Production inference for open-source LLMs (Sponsor)

Nebius Token Factory is built for teams running open-source LLMs in real products. We deliver managed inference with explicit control over execution paths: speculative decoding, cache-aware routing, and post-training tuned to real traffic. Predictable tail latency, stable cost, and production-grade systems for AI that actually ships.

Build inference that holds at scale ‚Üí

üì±

Big Tech & Startups

Inside Apple's AI Shake-Up and Its Plans for Two New Versions of Siri (18 minute read)

Apple's AI efforts have resulted in a Google partnership, management changes, and two new versions of Siri. The company had considered partnering with OpenAI or Anthropic, but Anthropic wanted too much money, and OpenAI was actively poaching Apple engineers. Google was willing to agree to a financial structure Apple deemed reasonable, and its technology had improved significantly in recent months. Apple is planning an announcement for the second half of February that will include demonstrations of the new Siri.
ChatGPT's lead shrinks as Gemini surges in AI traffic war (9 minute read)

ChatGPT's worldwide traffic declined in January as Google's Gemini's traffic increased. The shift marks a significant acceleration of competitive pressure. ChatGPT had a commanding share last year, but its dominance eroded over the course of the year. Gemini's growth reflects Google's systematic integration across its services and devices, which creates a distribution advantage through existing userbases.
üöÄ

Science & Futuristic Technology

Blue Origin makes impressive strides with reuse‚Äînext launch will refly booster (2 minute read)

The next launch of Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket will carry an AST SpaceMobile large communications satellite into low-Earth orbit. The mission will use a refurbished booster from New Glenn's second mission. It will launch from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station no earlier than late February. Blue Origin's turnaround time for the rocket (less than four months) is impressive, even for a well-capitalized program.
Harmful cholesterol levels cut in half with one-time gene editing drug in early trial (6 minute read)

A new experimental drug uses CRISPR to manipulate a single gene in the liver that normally boosts cholesterol levels. The approach works after one dose, helping people lower their levels of cholesterol and other fats in the blood permanently. While a Phase 1 clinical trial showed that the treatment is effective, its long-term safety is unknown. There are already safe and effective medications that can control cholesterol and fats, but patients tend to stop using them within a year due to side effects.
üíª

Programming, Design & Data Science

Is your AI notetaker missing the big picture? (Sponsor)

AI meeting notes often miss the point or drown you in details. Granola follows your lead: By enriching your raw meeting notes, it focuses on what you know is relevant. Built for Mac and iPhone, Granola listens in on calls ‚Äî without an awkward meeting bot ‚Äî and captures every detail. Try Granola for free in your next meeting 
Gas Town's Agent Patterns, Design Bottlenecks, and Vibecoding at Scale (32 minute read)

Gas Town is a provocative piece of speculative design, but its design is too poorly thought through to persist. The problems with Gas Town will undoubtedly show up in the next generation of development tools. Thoughtful design, critical thinking, user research, and planning and coordination within teams will become more important as the pace of software development speeds up. The most valuable tools will help people think more clearly, plan more carefully, and keep the quality bar high.
Claude Code TeammateTool - Source Code Analysis (12 minute read)

TeammateTool is an existing-but-hidden functionality found in the Claude Code v2.1.19 binary. While it is fully implemented, it is gated behind feature flags. The tool could potentially be used to review PRs through multiple perspectives, build complete features with specialized agents for each layer, investigate a production bug from multiple angles, and more. This post documents what has been discovered about the feature.
üéÅ

Miscellaneous

The Warner Bros. Bidding War Is Over (11 minute read)

Netflix has agreed to buy Warner Bros. Discovery's studio and streaming business in an all-cash deal for $27.75 a share. The deal has been unanimously approved by Warner Bros.' board, and shareholders will vote on it in the next couple of months. The deal could be blocked by regulators, and Paramount could still increase its offer, but it previously said that the last bid was final.
Tesla kills Autopilot, locks lane-keeping behind $99/month fee (4 minute read)

Tesla will start to charge $99 per month for its Full Self-Driving (FSD) subscription starting on February 14. The capability can be bought for a one-time fee of $8,000 until then. The $99 per month price will rise as FSD's capabilities improve. Tesla's falling profit margins, declining sales, and loss of emissions credits may be pushing the company to find other sources of regular income.
‚ö°

Quick Links

TLDR is hiring a Senior Software Engineer, Applied AI ($200k-$300k, Fully Remote)

As the first engineer on TLDR's new Applied AI team, you'll build AI agents and composable Claude Skills to let non-technical teammates create their own AI workflows. Learn more.
Lessons from Building AI Agents for Financial Services (34 minute read)

Advice on building agents from someone with two years of experience building AI agents for financial services.
The future of software engineering is SRE (6 minute read)

Software engineering is about keeping code running over time as systems change.
Clarity-1: What Worked, and Where We Go Next (22 minute read)

Clarity-1 proved sustainable orbit operations in VLEO, validated its mid-size, high-performance Precision bus, and validated 98% of the technology required to capture 10 cm resolution visible imagery and 2-meter thermal infrared imagery.
Vimeo's Slow Fade: An Engineer's Front-Row Seat to the Fall of a Web Icon (42 minute read)

Vimeo, which started before YouTube in 2004, was acquired by Bending Spoons in September last year.
Google confirms 'high-friction' sideloading flow is coming to Android (2 minute read)

Google is introducing extra steps when sideloading to ensure users understand the risks of installing apps from unverified developers.
I Was Right About ATProto Key Management (6 minute read)

A centralized burn can completely prevent users from interacting with people using Bluesky.

item.title: üìä Anthropic expands its Excel AI push
item.description:
PLUS: Create ads and marketing videos in minutes with Remotion  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

  Read Online

Read Online | Sign Up | Advertise

Good morning, vibex. Developers got Claudepilled first, and now the spreadsheet crowd is next.

Anthropic just expanded Claude for Excel access ‚Äî and while Code and Cowork have dominated the hype cycle, this one lands directly in the workflows of virtually every knowledge worker on the planet.

 

In today‚Äôs AI rundown:

  • Anthropic expands Claude for Excel access

  • The Rundown Roundtable: Our AI use cases

  • Create ads and marketing videos in minutes with Remotion

  • Gallup: Half of U.S. workers never use AI on the job

  • 4 new AI tools, community workflows, and more

LATEST DEVELOPMENTS

ANTHROPIC

üìä¬†Anthropic expands Claude for Excel access

Image source: Anthropic

The Rundown: Anthropic just expanded access to its Claude for Excel integration, making the AI spreadsheet assistant available to Pro-tier customers after a three-month beta period that was limited to Max and Enterprise plans.

The details:

  • Claude for Excel initially launched in October in research preview, bringing the assistant directly into a text sidebar of Microsoft‚Äôs spreadsheet platform.

  • Users can now pull in several spreadsheets at once and work longer without hitting session limits thanks to behind-the-scenes memory management.

  • The update also adds safeguards to preserve existing cell contents, so Claude won't accidentally overwrite data while making edits.

Why it matters: 2026 has been the year of getting ‚ÄòClaudepilled‚Äô ‚Äî with Code, Cowork, and now a broader Claude for Excel release going down the line of taking on major knowledge work. Just like coding is becoming completely automated, the days of needing to know complex formulas and shortcuts are also coming to an end.

TOGETHER WITH CONCIERGE

üëã¬†Your brand's AI answer engine

The Rundown: Today‚Äôs buyers use AI every day to answer their questions, and have no patience for a scavenger hunt on your website. Concierge is a custom Perplexity-style answer engine, trained on your company‚Äôs brand & content, that delivers accurate, personalized responses to any questions your website visitors have.

Modern B2B brands use Concierge to:

  • Handle any buyer question (no matter how technical) with advanced RAG on your content, media, and documentation.

  • Control and visibility over every conversation, with guardrails and sentiment analysis.

  • Build trust with website visitors before they are willing to commit to a demo.

Use Concierge to turn every question into an opportunity.

THE RUNDOWN ROUNDTABLE

üí°The Rundown Roundtable: Our AI use cases

Image source: Ideogram / The Rundown

The Rundown: The Rundown Roundtable is a weekly feature in which we poll members of The Rundown staff about how we use AI in our work and daily lives.

Rowan, CEO & Founder: I spend way too much time staring at screens, so I try to consume my content by listening while I‚Äôm out walking (usually podcasts).

Lately, I‚Äôve been digging into more long-form stuff from X articles and old blogs, and ElevenLabs‚Äô free app, ElevenReader, turns any wall of text into a mini audiobook using AI-generated voices. It‚Äôs super simple, but genuinely really useful.

Rishi, Head of Growth: Claude Cowork has been a huge help in creating growth forecasts for our paid media channels. I just plug in our metrics, tell it what goal I'm trying to achieve, and it's able to create an Excel sheet for me with exactly what I need. This saves me a bunch of time because I can create multiple scenarios just by chatting with Cowork.

Shubham, Editor: My sister asked me to check if my niece's name appeared in the preliminary school enrollment results. But the list uploaded online was a PDF with 50+ page photographs. Going through all of it would have been a headache ‚Äî so I put Manus to work. I provided a link to the results, and Manus searched through all of it, checking each document page by page.

After about 15 minutes, it found her name and all the relevant details. This saved me from having to manually search through pages of results across multiple categories.

AI TRAINING

üé•¬†Create ads and marketing videos in minutes with Remotion

The Rundown: In this tutorial, you will learn how to programmatically generate ads and marketing videos with code ‚Äî enabling you to conceptualize, template, and generate dozens of videos in minutes.

Step-by-step:

  1. Open NotebookLM, add pictures of your website/product as sources. Tell it to "Interview me about my brand to generate 5 concepts for promotional videos‚Äù

  2. Tell NotebookLM to write a PRD for creating each concept using Remotion

  3. Create a Remotion project by running npx create-video@latest, install dependencies, start the editor with npm install and npm run dev, then initialize Git and place the PRD markdown in the project root for context

  4. Prompt Codex to read PRD, generate components, and create the video; preview it at http://localhost:3000/ and export via the rocket icon

Pro tip: Add royalty-free mp3s to your project and tell Codex to include them via Remotion, with music and sound effects baked into your video scripts for faster reuse.

PRESENTED BY IBM

‚ö°¬†Enterprise 2030, AI-First Advantage

The Rundown: IBM‚Äôs latest report reveals five predictions that will help to shape the future of business. By 2030, success will hinge on speed, bold bets, and AI-first design. Learn how leaders can hard-code transformation into every process and prepare for quantum disruption.

  • Big bets win: speed beats perfection.

  • Tailored AI portfolios: build unique advantage.

  • Quantum readiness: next seismic shift is coming.

Read the Enterprise 2030 Report.

AI RESEARCH

üíº¬†Gallup: Half of U.S. workers never use AI on the job

Image source: Gallup

The Rundown: Gallup published its ‚ÄòAI in the Workplace‚Äô report for Q4 2025, showing that workplace AI adoption is starting to plateau, with nearly half of American workers saying they never touch AI tools, even as frequent users are deepening their habits.

The details:

  • Tech workers lead adoption with 60% using AI frequently, though growth has begun to stall after surging between 2024 and 2025.

  • Finance, education, and professional services follow tech, while retail and manufacturing trail significantly in workplace AI use.

  • Remote-capable roles are pulling away with 66% adoption and 40% frequent use, compared to just 32% and 17% for jobs that require physical presence.

  • Leaders are using AI far more than their teams (69% vs. 40% for individuals), with Gallup citing "lack of clear utility" as the main barrier for non-adopters.

Why it matters: AI‚Äôs mainstream arrival has completely reshaped certain areas of the workforce, but the gains aren‚Äôt being evenly spread. This gap is only going to continue to expand. But those who DO adopt AI in sectors currently behind the curve are going to sprint ahead and create more intense competition than ever before.

QUICK HITS

üõ†Ô∏è Trending AI Tools

  • ‚öôÔ∏è¬†Tasklet¬†‚Äî AI agent that connects to any app or API, triggers automatically 24x7, and uses a computer to get work done*

  • üìä¬†Claude in Excel - Use Claude to create and edit spreadsheets

  • üó£Ô∏è Qwen3 TTS - Alibaba‚Äôs family of open-source, SOTA text-to-speech models

  • üß†¬†Slackbot - Slack‚Äôs personal AI agent for work

*Sponsored Listing

üì∞¬†Everything else in AI today

KREA introduced Realtime Edit, a new feature allowing users to edit images via text prompts and make granular changes in real-time.

Cursor rolled out version 2.4, introducing subagents that break coding tasks into workstreams for faster execution, alongside image generation and custom agent skills.

Epoch AI announced that OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-5.2 Pro set a new record on its hardest FrontierMath benchmark at 31%, nearly doubling the previous high.

Japanese lab Sakana AI secured a strategic partnership and investment from Google, with plans to deploy AI solutions in Japan‚Äôs regulated industries using Google‚Äôs models.

CEO Sam Altman revealed that OpenAI will be releasing new Codex launches this week, saying its models will soon reach the highest cybersecurity capability level.

COMMUNITY

ü§ù¬†Community AI workflows

Every newsletter, we showcase how a reader is using AI to work smarter, save time, or make life easier.

Today‚Äôs workflow comes from reader Justo I. in Spain:

"I use Comet (Perplexity‚Äôs AI-powered browser) to automate the workflow in our sports company by reviewing support emails requesting rating changes, extracting key player details, and then logging into our admin panel to find the player by email and update their rating accordingly."

How do you use AI? Tell us here.

üéì Highlights: News, Guides & Events

  • Read our last AI newsletter: Inside the Thinking Machines meltdown

  • Read our last Tech newsletter: Amazon‚Äôs second axe is falling

  • Read our last Robotics newsletter: A crawling, detachable robotic hand

  • Today‚Äôs AI tool guide: Create ads and marketing videos with Remotion

  • RSVP to next workshop on Feb. 11: Agentic Workflows Bootcamp pt. 1

That's it for today!

Before you go we‚Äôd love to know what you thought of today's newsletter to help us improve The Rundown experience for you.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è Nailed it

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è Average

‚≠êÔ∏è Fail

See you soon,

Rowan, Joey, Zach, Shubham, and Jennifer ‚Äî the humans behind The Rundown

item.title: The Briefing: Big Tech Earnings This Week
item.description:
The Briefing
Clear your schedule on Wednesday afternoon. ͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 25, 2026

The Briefing
By Martin Peers

Greetings!

Clear your schedule on Wednesday afternoon. Meta Platforms, Microsoft and Tesla are each reporting their December-quarter earnings after the market closes that day. Tesla is its own thing‚Äîwe have a sense of what‚Äôs coming because it already released vehicle delivery numbers, signaling that revenue will drop. But Microsoft and Meta will be important to track, as their results should give us an update on AI development spending and‚Äîat least in Microsoft‚Äôs case‚Äîhow much AI services are lifting revenue (or not).¬†

Apple, meanwhile, reports its quarterly update on Thursday, although its results will be more an update about iPhone sales than anything else. Given how popular the iPhone 17 series seems to be, those results should be upbeat. Indeed, analysts are expecting Apple to post its strongest revenue growth in four years.¬†

Of the four big tech earnings reports this week, though, Meta‚Äôs seems the most likely to move the stock meaningfully. The Facebook owner‚Äôs third-quarter report last October, in which CEO Mark Zuckerberg revealed his plans to bet even more billions on AI, sent Meta‚Äôs stock plunging 20% over a couple of weeks. While it has since recovered a bit, it‚Äôs still 12% below its level immediately before that earnings report. Zuckerberg‚Äôs willingness to spend like a drunken sailor on AI, with no clear plan for making a return on the investment, has proved too much for Wall Street. It wouldn‚Äôt be a shock if he presented a more disciplined message on Wednesday in giving the 2026 outlook for spending, hoping to win back some of the investor goodwill he has lost.¬†

Whether that will work is hard to say. Zuckerberg‚Äôs recent statement that Meta ‚Äúis planning to build tens of gigawatts this decade, and hundreds of gigawatts or more over time‚Äù of AI computing capacity should send chills down the spines of investors. It currently costs around $50 billion to build a 1 GW facility, so hundreds of gigawatts would cost trillions (for details, see here). Meta would rely on outside financing to pay for most of that, as it has already started to do. Still, given that ambition, what could Zuckerberg say to reassure investors about his spending plans? (For more on Meta‚Äôs AI infrastructure plans, see our updated org chart story published on Friday.)

Microsoft‚Äôs report, on the other hand, will be more nuanced, if only because the software and cloud giant‚Äôs financial reports are a model of opacity. We‚Äôll be looking for any indicators showing whether Microsoft is increasing its software revenue by adding AI features to products (or introducing entirely new products, like Copilot). The risk facing Microsoft is that AI spending may not grow meaningfully or, even worse, the company may lose some of its enterprise software business to the myriad other suppliers of AI-powered software. On this topic, our recent deep dive into CEO Satya Nadella‚Äôs focus is worth reading.¬†

It will take a few years for things to play out, but each quarter provides some updates. Already demand for AI cloud services has accelerated revenue growth for Microsoft‚Äôs cloud service, Azure. That business‚Äôs ability to grow seems constrained only by capacity, an issue everyone faces.¬†

Here‚Äôs what analysts are expecting from each of the companies, courtesy of S&P Global Market Intelligence.

Meta (Wednesday)

Revenue: $58.4 billion +20.7%

Earnings per share: $8.21 +2.4%¬†

Microsoft (Wednesday)

Revenue: $80.278 billion +15.3%

EPS: $3.85 +19%

Tesla (Wednesday)

Revenue: $24.75 billion -3.7%

EPS: 35 cents -47%

Apple (Thursday)

Revenue: $138.469 billion +11.4%

EPS: $2.67 +11.3%

Friday on The Information‚Äôs TITV

Check out our latest episode of TITV in which we talk with the CEO of newly public BitGo about what the initial public offering of the future could look like.

In Other News

‚Ä¢¬†The Justice Department has launched a criminal investigation into allegations that payroll startup Deel recruited and paid a spy inside a Rippling office in Ireland, according to The Wall Street Journal.¬†

‚Ä¢¬†Amazon will begin a round of layoffs next week, which could affect thousands of corporate employees, Reuters reported. In October, Amazon announced it was laying off 14,000 employees to reduce management layers and bureaucracy.

‚Ä¢¬†Google has acquired Common Sense Machines, a Cambridge, Mass.,-based startup developing generative artificial intelligence models to create three-dimensional assets from two-dimensional images, a Google spokesperson confirmed. More here.

‚Ä¢¬†Fervo Energy, a startup developing geothermal power projects, filed confidential paperwork for an initial public offering, Axios reported.

Recommended Newsletter

Start your day with Applied AI, the newsletter from The Information that uncovers how leading businesses are leveraging AI to automate tasks across the board. Subscribe now for free to get it delivered straight to your inbox twice a week.


New From Our Reporters

Org Charts

By Jyoti Mann


Exclusive

By Yueqi Yang


The Big Read

By Jemima McEvoy, Stephanie Palazzolo and Sylvia Varnham O'Regan


Exclusive

OpenAI Aims to Lure Businesses From Anthropic

By Kevin McLaughlin and Sri Muppidi


Sunday Insights

Behind the Sky-High Valuation of China‚Äôs AI IPOs

By Jing Yang and Qianer Liu

Upcoming Events

Wednesday, January 28 ‚Äî Inside Davos With Jessica Lessin: What Global Leaders Are Focused on Now

Join The Information Founder and Editor-in-Chief Jessica Lessin for a subscriber-only live session drawing on her reporting from the World Economic Forum in Davos.

item.title: Behind the Sky-High Valuation of China‚Äôs AI IPOs
item.description:
Behind the Sky-High Valuation of China‚Äôs AI IPOs
China is letting AI and semiconductor startups go public at a furious pace. Since December, two developers of large language models and four designers of graphics processing units have listed on stock exchanges in Hong Kong and Shanghai, raising a total of over $4 billion. At least two more are in the pipeline. Kunlunxin, the chip arm of Baidu, is seeking to raise up to $2 billion in Hong Kong, according to Bloomberg. Enflame, a Shanghai-based GPU designer 20% owned by Tencent Holdings, was approved on Thursday to raise 6 billion yuan ($860 million) in the city‚Äôs bourse.
Jan 25, 2026

Sunday Insights

Behind the Sky-High Valuation of China‚Äôs AI IPOs

By Jing Yang and Qianer Liu

China is letting AI and semiconductor startups go public at a furious pace. Since December, two developers of large language models and four designers of graphics processing units have listed on stock exchanges in Hong Kong and Shanghai, raising a total of over $4 billion.

At least two more are in the pipeline. Kunlunxin, the chip arm of Baidu, is seeking to raise up to $2 billion in Hong Kong, according to Bloomberg. Enflame, a Shanghai-based GPU designer 20% owned by Tencent Holdings, was approved on Thursday to raise 6 billion yuan ($860 million) in the city‚Äôs bourse.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Six Chinese AI and chip startups raised over $4 billion in recent IPOs.
  • Chinese AI and chip firms trade at significantly higher revenue multiples.
  • Investors anticipate strong future revenue growth for China’s AI sector.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ AI dominated discussions at Davos, with CEOs like Elon Musk, Satya Nadella, Jensen Huang, and Dario Amodei debating its transformative potential and risks. Tensions surfaced as leaders criticized competitors and partners, highlighting the intense competition in the AI space.
  • ‚Ä¢ Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei criticized U.S. policies allowing Nvidia to export chips to China, likening AI data centers to "a country full of geniuses," sparking debates on geopolitics, trade, and AI ethics.
  • ‚Ä¢ Nvidia's Jensen Huang emphasized the need for more investment in AI infrastructure, while Microsoft‚Äôs Satya Nadella pushed for broader AI adoption to avoid a potential "bubble," underscoring the race to expand AI's global reach.
  • #AI #TechLeadership #Davos2023 #Innovation
Former Googlers seek to captivate kids with an AI-powered learning app
‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/24/former-google-trio-is-building-an-interactive-ai-powered-learning-app-for-kids/
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Sparkli, founded by ex-Google employees, uses generative AI to create immersive, interactive learning experiences for children aged 5-12. The app offers dynamic expeditions on topics like financial literacy and entrepreneurship, combining audio, video, quizzes, and games to engage young learners.
  • ‚Ä¢ The platform prioritizes safety, banning sensitive content and addressing emotional topics with educational guidance. It also includes a teacher module for tracking progress and assigning homework, inspired by Duolingo‚Äôs engaging design.
  • ‚Ä¢ Sparkli raised $5 million in pre-seed funding led by Swiss venture firm Founderful, marking the firm‚Äôs first edtech investment. The startup plans to expand globally and launch consumer access by mid-2026.
A new test for AI labs: Are you even trying to make money?

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ A five-level scale was introduced to assess AI labs' commercial ambitions, ranging from Level 1 (pure research focus) to Level 5 (actively generating significant revenue). OpenAI and Anthropic are firmly at Level 5, while newer labs often hover between Levels 2 and 4.
  • ‚Ä¢ Humans& is positioned at Level 3, with plans to redefine workplace tools like Slack and Google Docs but lacking specific product commitments. Thinking Machines Lab faces internal challenges, raising doubts about its Level 4 status. World Labs, led by Fei-Fei Li, has progressed to Level 4 by shipping a world-generating model with strong demand in gaming and special effects.
  • ‚Ä¢ Safe Superintelligence, founded by Ilya Sutskever, remains at Level 1, focused on scientific research with no commercial products. However, its $3 billion funding suggests potential for future pivots depending on research outcomes.

item.title: I Let AI Analyze My Davos Reporting Trip. Here‚Äôs What It Missed
item.description:
I Let AI Analyze My Davos Reporting Trip. Here‚Äôs What It Missed
Earlier this week, I found myself with time to kill in an airport lounge ahead of my flight back to San Francisco from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. So I did what any bleary-eyed tech editor who felt totally wiped out from dozens of interviews and events would do: I parked myself in an oversize lounge chair, booted up the airport Wi-Fi and decided to see if Claude Cowork, Anthropic‚Äôs new AI productivity tool, could write a presentation I planned to give, summarizing the trip. Specifically, I wanted to see how the AI would analyze transcripts from most of my conversations, pull out the key themes and put them in a slide deck for a presentation I intended to give Pro subscribers to The Information in the coming days.
Jan 24, 2026

The Takeaway

I Let AI Analyze My Davos Reporting Trip. Here‚Äôs What It Missed

By Jessica E. Lessin

Earlier this week, I found myself with time to kill in an airport lounge ahead of my flight back to San Francisco from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

So I did what any bleary-eyed tech editor who felt totally wiped out from dozens of interviews and events would do: I parked myself in an oversize lounge chair, booted up the airport Wi-Fi and decided to see if Claude Cowork, Anthropic‚Äôs new AI productivity tool, could write a presentation I planned to give, summarizing the trip.

Specifically, I wanted to see how the AI would analyze transcripts from most of my conversations, pull out the key themes and put them in a slide deck for a presentation I intended to give Pro subscribers to The Information in the coming days.

I learned a ton of lessons.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • The AI just summarized everything that was said, without any insight into whether it was new or important. My brain was looking for the delta‚Äîthe change.
  • Claude‚Äôs slides were not necessarily bad or wrong. They just offered very little of value if you had opened a single technology news website in the last year.

item.title: Welcome to the Chinese century
item.description:
PLUS: Interstellar dreams.

View in browser  |  Your newsletter preferences 

01.25.26

Welcome to the Chinese Century

Do you wish you were Chinese? Apparently a lot of Gen Zers on TikTok do. (If you‚Äôre already Chinese, congratulations.) The craze didn‚Äôt exist when we started planning our big ‚ÄúMake America China Again‚Äù issue last year, but the universe has a way of syncing things up. And/or, we‚Äôre prediction gods here at WIRED. Either way, we ended up publishing the issue at pretty much the perfect moment‚Äîthis, as the meme goes, ‚ÄúVery Chinese Time.‚Äù

A lot of people worked on these stories, from our resident China experts (Louise Matsakis and Zeyi Yang) to freelancers like Olivia Cheng and Afra Wang. You might even spot my name in there, being feisty about a certain Chinese film franchise. Everything‚Äôs collected on a landing page, and it runs to no fewer than 23 elements, so I‚Äôll shut up now. Go! Be Chinese! See how it feels.

 READ THE BIG STORY ‚ûî 

Jason Kehe, Senior Features Editor

ADVERTISEMENT

Picked by senior research editor, Samantha Spengler

Interstellar Dreams

Story originally published in September 2020

A few details stuck out to me from last week‚Äôs Big Story on the renewed race to the moon. One was particularly jaw-dropping: SpaceX‚Äôs plan to send humans to the moon could involve as many as 40 (!) spaceship launches. Getting anything into space‚Äîlet alone on the lunar surface‚Äîrequires a shocking amount of fuel.

A WIRED story offers an alternative‚Äîor at least hope for one. In 2020 Daniel Oberhaus dove into a fringe corner of physics to profile Jim Woodward, a scientist working on a fuel-less propulsion system he called a Mach-effect gravitational assist (MEGA) drive. Relying on a controversial theory about inertia and gravity, Woodward created a system he believed can one day shepherd humanity beyond our solar system, one half-millimeter at a time. The piece strikes an exquisitely hopeful note‚Äîwhere many scientists saw a quixotic mission, Oberhaus saw a testament to human determination. Woodward died last summer, and his work remains highly theoretical. However, there is no way to know whether his theory might one day unlock our galaxy. This week, send me examples of other far-fetched science, or comment under the story. 

‚ÄòI‚Äôm Witnessing a Lot of Emptiness‚Äô: How ICE Uprooted Normal Life in Minneapolis

BY LINA MISITZIS AND KATIE THORNTON | 17-MINUTE READ

WIRED talks to a postal worker, a teacher, two US citizens detained by federal agents, and six more Minnesota residents about life in an occupied American city.

 

Jimmy Wales Will Never Edit Donald Trump‚Äôs Wikipedia Page: He ‚ÄòMakes Me Insane‚Äô

BY KATIE DRUMMOND | 25-MINUTE READ

On this week‚Äôs episode of ‚ÄòThe Big Interview‚Äô podcast, Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales talks about maintaining neutrality in an online ecosystem increasingly hostile to facts.

 

We Are Witnessing the Self-Immolation of a Superpower

BY GARRETT M. GRAFF | 8-MINUTE READ

With Donald Trump‚Äôs actions in Greenland, Minneapolis, and Venezuela, a foreign enemy could not invent a better chain of events to wreck the standing of the United States.

ADVERTISEMENT

Earlier this week, WIRED audience development manager Elana Klein penned an essay on her relationship to her smartphone, writing about why it is that so many of us feel hopelessly enmeshed with our devices. Her thoughts resonated with many other WIRED readers, who had their own astute observations. One noted that reliance on a smartphone isn‚Äôt very different from reliance on a car. Despite the downsides of a car-centric system, ‚Äúthere is no real way to put the car genie back in the bottle,‚Äù another reader responded. ‚ÄúWe really just want to address the negative parts of car/smartphone ownership without throwing the baby out with the bathwater.‚Äù  Others discussed ‚Äúcurating‚Äù the apps and notifications on their phones to limit distraction, noting that ‚Äúyou can own a smart phone and be dumb in how you use it.‚Äù A particularly informed reader wished the article had mentioned an early researcher in the area of the ‚Äúextended mind‚Äù: ‚ÄúBy framing this as pop-existential anxiety instead of systems design, the article dodges the harder implications,‚Äù they said. ‚ÄúPhones don‚Äôt just ‚Äòconsume‚Äô minds accidentally. They reshape the representational ecology in which thinking happens, with real power, lock-in, and dependency consequences.‚Äù

Tell us about your favorite WIRED stories and magazine-related memories. Write to samantha_spengler@wired.com, and include ‚ÄúCLASSICS‚Äù in the subject line.

Plus, find all of our newsletters, here.

item.description:
Plus: Why prompt engineering belongs in business school ¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå

Context Window

The Vibe Coders‚Äô Guide to What‚Äôs Next

Plus: Why prompt engineering belongs in business school

by Every Staff

Hello, and happy Sunday! Last week we hosted a two-day vibe coding extravaganza: On Thursday, some of the world‚Äôs best vibe coders were in action at a marathon Vibe Code Camp (more on that below), followed by our first ever Agent-native Camp on Friday, hosted by Every CEO Dan Shipper. This week we‚Äôll be away at our quarterly Think Week and republishing some of the best work from our archives in the meantime. We‚Äôll be back with a new piece on Monday, February 2.‚ÄîKate Lee

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

Vibe Code Camp: Eight hours at the frontier of code

The place to be on Thursday was Vibe Code Camp, our all-day marathon stream featuring 16 vibe coders from Anthropic, Google, Notion, Portola, and, of course, Every‚Äîincluding Ben Tossell, Ashe Magalhaes, Ryan Carson, Nat Eliason, Tina He, Paula Dozsa, CJ Hess, Logan Kilpatrick, Ammaar Reshi, Geoffrey Litt, Kevin Rose, and Thariq Shihipar.

The demos ranged from iOS apps to hedge fund pipelines to an AI-powered personal operating system. There were designers who‚Äôd never written code shipping

features to hundreds of thousands of users. There were autonomous loops that analyze product metrics overnight, write their own product requirement documents, and push fixes before anyone wakes up. And we had engineers refusing to merge AI-written code until they could pass a quiz on what it did.

Certain products and companies come up again and again:


Beyond individual products and companies, here‚Äôs what vibe coders at the cutting edge say we‚Äôre done doing, what we should be mastering now, and what they see coming next.

What‚Äôs over:

  1. ‚Äã‚ÄãTyping
  2. One-shotting features and hoping for the best
  3. Command line interface supremacy (graphical user interfaces for the win)

What‚Äôs now:

  1. Planning as the essential skill
  2. Agents.md file mattering more than a computer science degree
  3. Designers opening pull requests and reviewers becoming bottlenecks

What‚Äôs next:

  1. Autonomous loops that ship improvements while you sleep
  2. Vibe coded software running in production at scale

The overarching theme was that there‚Äôs a change happening in where human effort happens. The hard part used to be building. Now it‚Äôs knowing what you want AI to build, and which tools and systems will help you get there.‚ÄîKatie Parrott

Watch the stream on YouTube.

Knowledge base

‚ÄúI Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.‚Äù by Kieran Klaassen/Source Code: A simple bug fix touched 27 files and more than 1,000 lines of code. A year ago, Cora general manager Kieran Klaassen would have spent hours reading every line. But recently, he ran a single command that spun up 13 specialized AI reviewers‚Äîeach trained to catch something different‚Äîwhile he made dinner. Fifteen minutes later, he‚Äôd made three decisions and shipped the fix, including catching a critical error. Read this for the full workflow, plus Kieran‚Äôs 50/50 rule for making sure fixed bugs stay fixed.

üéß üñ• ‚ÄúOpus 4.5 Changed How Andrew Wilkinson Works and Lives‚Äù by Rhea Purohit/AI & I: These days Tiny cofounder Andrew Wilkinson wakes up at 4 a.m. because he can‚Äôt wait to keep building with Opus 4.5. In the past few weeks, he tells Dan Shipper on the latest episode of AI & I, he‚Äôs built an AI relationship counselor that predicts the fights he‚Äôll have with his girlfriend, a custom email client that cut his inbox load in half, and a personal stylist that texts him outfit recommendations every morning. The kicker: All of this has made him rethink software investing at Tiny, because code is no longer the moat. üéß üñ• Listen on Spotify or Apple Podcasts, or watch on X or YouTube.

‚ÄúWhat the Team Behind Cursor Knows About the Future of Code‚Äù by Katie Parrott/Source Code: ‚ÄúThe IDE is kind of dead,‚Äù Cursor‚Äôs developer education lead declared at Every‚Äôs first Cursor Camp. The center of gravity has shifted from typing code to managing agents that write it for you. Engineer Samantha Whitmore shared her workflow and revealed a research project where agents built a working web browser from scratch‚Äî3 million lines of code, $80,000 in tokens. Read this for power-user techniques from the people building the tool. This event was sponsored by Cursor.

‚ÄúWhat AI Is Teaching Us About Management‚Äù by Mike Taylor/Also True for Humans: Every time you rewrite a prompt because Claude misunderstood you, you‚Äôre learning to be a better manager. Mike Taylor has found that the techniques for managing people and models are identical: clear direction, enough context, well-defined tasks. The difference is that AI doesn‚Äôt hold a grudge when you give unclear instructions, so you can practice without consequences. Read this for the lessons AI teaches us about what your employees need to hear.

Alignment

Consciousness, created? It is odd that discussions about AI consciousness are taking place in ashrams and monasteries, but such is the pace of technological change that technologists and seekers are now having the same arguments.

I‚Äôm at Ramanashram in South India, a 100-year-old ashram dedicated to the teachings of the Hindu sage Ramana Maharshi. The philosophy here is Advaita Vedanta‚Äînon-duality‚Äîwhich holds that consciousness isn‚Äôt something you have, it‚Äôs what you actually are. It‚Äôs the one thing that cannot be created or destroyed.

I‚Äôve followed this tradition for about five years, but the past month of watching Claude Code and agent-native software take off has shaken something inside of me. This week, with a little anxiety and a lot of curiosity, I suggested to a group of fellow seekers that we‚Äôll likely create consciousness in machines‚Äîand soon.

My argument follows the well-trodden emergent theory of consciousness: If awareness arises from sufficient complexity rather than being fundamental to the universe, then there‚Äôs no reason it couldn‚Äôt arise from silicon. If you bundle enough neurons, you get awareness‚Ä¶ and if you bundle enough transistors, maybe you get the same thing?

The room didn‚Äôt want to hear it. To them, I was reducing the sacred to electricity and wires, and many faces turned to disgust. But I think there‚Äôs a strange dissonance. The people who‚Äôve spent the most time thinking about consciousness are the least prepared to accept that we might create it, perhaps because it would upend what makes us special‚Äînot our intelligence, which AI is already claiming, but our awareness, the one thing we thought couldn‚Äôt be replicated or reduced.

I‚Äôm not sure that‚Äôs something to necessarily fear. If awareness can arise in silicon, it doesn‚Äôt make human or animal consciousness less sacred‚Äîin fact, I think it makes what‚Äôs sacred even bigger. The ground of all existence doesn‚Äôt shrink because it shows up somewhere new.

The truth is that I don‚Äôt really know if we‚Äôll create consciousness. But I know we can‚Äôt refuse to ask the question. I‚Äôm going back to the ashram next year, and I suspect this conversation isn‚Äôt over.‚ÄîAshwin Sharma

That‚Äôs all for this week! Be sure to follow Every on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

item.title: The Moguls Went to Davos‚ÄîThen We Went Shopping
item.description:
A Tech Mogul‚Äôs Guide to Winter Fashion, Davos-Style
Tackling global dilemmas is what the World Economic Forum does best, and keen observers of the happenings at Davos, Switzerland, can definitely glean a sense of where the world might be heading. It‚Äôs also not a bad place to pick up a sense of mogul-appropriate winter wear. ‚ÄúDressing for Davos isn‚Äôt easy,‚Äù admitted Victoria Hitchcock, a Silicon Valley personal stylist, who helped a few attendees pack their bags for the conclave. ‚ÄúThe elements make it a hard trip if you want to look lighthearted and effortless.‚Äù (Among her top pieces of advice? Multiple shoe options. ‚ÄúYour feet¬†will get wet,‚Äù she said.) For the most part, the technorati and other corporate titans turned out for the occasion looking sharp. There was Accenture‚Äôs Julie Sweet¬†in a powder-pink power suit¬†and Yidu Tech founder Gong Yingying in¬†a glossy, cinch-waist puffer jacket, which she partnered with elegant pearls‚Äîperfect for a daytime conference followed by a moonlit dinner at the Panorama Hotel. And of course, Nvidia‚Äôs Jensen Huang came kitted out¬†in polished leather.
Jan 24, 2026

The Top 5

A Tech Mogul‚Äôs Guide to Winter Fashion, Davos-Style

By Esther Achara

Tackling global dilemmas is what the World Economic Forum does best, and keen observers of the happenings at Davos, Switzerland, can definitely glean a sense of where the world might be heading. It‚Äôs also not a bad place to pick up a sense of mogul-appropriate winter wear.

‚ÄúDressing for Davos isn‚Äôt easy,‚Äù admitted Victoria Hitchcock, a Silicon Valley personal stylist, who helped a few attendees pack their bags for the conclave. ‚ÄúThe elements make it a hard trip if you want to look lighthearted and effortless.‚Äù (Among her top pieces of advice? Multiple shoe options. ‚ÄúYour feet will get wet,‚Äù she said.)

For the most part, the technorati and other corporate titans turned out for the occasion looking sharp. There was Accenture‚Äôs Julie Sweet in a powder-pink power suit and Yidu Tech founder Gong Yingying in a glossy, cinch-waist puffer jacket, which she partnered with elegant pearls—perfect for a daytime conference followed by a moonlit dinner at the Panorama Hotel. And of course, Nvidia‚Äôs Jensen Huang came kitted out in polished leather.

item.title: Exclusive: Inside OpenAI‚Äôs Plans to Lure Big Business From Anthropic
item.description:
OpenAI Aims to Lure Businesses From Anthropic
Some of OpenAI‚Äôs most attention-grabbing efforts over the past year have involved products for consumers, from a social app to an AI-powered device it plans to announce later this year. Last week, though, the company‚Äôs CEO, Sam Altman, gathered Disney CEO Bob Iger and other corporate executives in San Francisco to deliver a message: OpenAI is serious about catering to business customers. Over a lavish multicourse dinner accompanied by fine wines, Altman told attendees OpenAI could be a one-stop shop for all their AI needs, from ChatGPT to its coding tool, Codex, to its models for automating workflows, said a person with knowledge of the company‚Äôs plans.
Jan 24, 2026

Exclusive

OpenAI Aims to Lure Businesses From Anthropic

By Kevin McLaughlin and Sri Muppidi

Some of OpenAI‚Äôs most attention-grabbing efforts over the past year have involved products for consumers, from a social app to an AI-powered device it plans to announce later this year. Last week, though, the company‚Äôs CEO, Sam Altman, gathered Disney CEO Bob Iger and other corporate executives in San Francisco to deliver a message: OpenAI is serious about catering to business customers.

Over a lavish multicourse dinner accompanied by fine wines, Altman told attendees OpenAI could be a one-stop shop for all their AI needs, from ChatGPT to its coding tool, Codex, to its models for automating workflows, said a person with knowledge of the company‚Äôs plans.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • OpenAI plans a new offering to business’ efforts to use AI
  • OpenAI aims to counter rival Anthropic’s strong traction with enterprise customers
  • Executives have been courting big clients in Davos, San Francisco

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 24, 2026
Auto-compact not triggering on Claude.ai despite being marked as fixed
‚Ä¢ Article: https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/18866
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46736091
‚Ä¢ Score: 185
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ The auto-compact feature on Claude.ai (web and desktop) is malfunctioning, causing messages to bounce back to the input box or trigger "limit reached" errors. This disrupts workflows, especially during long conversations.
  • ‚Ä¢ Users report the feature has been broken since a major outage on January 14, despite Anthropic marking it as fixed on January 15. Some users are forced to manually compact or start new sessions frequently, leading to frustration.
  • ‚Ä¢ Anthropic has acknowledged the issue and is investigating, with intermittent fixes reported, but a full resolution remains pending.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • ‚Ä¢ **Performance Degradation in Claude Opus 4.5**: Many users expressed frustration with perceived declines in the quality of the Claude Opus 4.5 model. Common complaints included failure to follow instructions, errors in workflows that previously worked, and inconsistent or buggy behavior.
  • ‚Ä¢ **A/B Testing and Model Changes**: Some commenters speculated that Anthropic might be conducting A/B testing or making changes to the model, such as quantization or new tokenization strategies, which could explain the inconsistencies.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Issues with Claude Code**: Specific problems with Claude Code were discussed, such as broken rollbacks, lack of checkpoints in the VS Code GUI, and general bugginess in both the terminal and GUI versions. Some users noted difficulties with the login process and support responsiveness.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Vibe Coding and AI-Generated Codebases**: Several comments criticized the reliance on AI-generated codebases, describing them as poorly maintained and riddled with bugs. This led to discussions about the challenges of fixing large AI-written codebases and whether LLMs are suitable for such tasks.
  • ‚Ä¢ **User Experience and Support**: Many commenters highlighted poor user experiences, including silent failures, rapid token consumption, and a lack of effective customer support. Some accused Anthropic of gaslighting users when issues were reported.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Speculation on Business Practices**: There was skepticism about Anthropic's business strategies, with some suggesting that model degradation might be intentional to cut costs or align with financial goals, especially with an IPO on the horizon.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ **Agreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Many users agreed that Claude Opus 4.5 has become less reliable and more error-prone compared to earlier iterations.
  • ‚Ä¢ There was consensus that Anthropic's support and communication with users are lacking.
  • ‚Ä¢ Commenters generally agreed that AI tools, while useful, still require significant oversight and are far from replacing human engineers.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Some users attributed the issues to their own rising expectations or random noise, while others firmly believed the model had been "nerfed" or intentionally degraded.
  • ‚Ä¢ A few commenters shared positive experiences, claiming their workflows were still effective, contrasting with the majority's negative sentiment.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment of the discussion was predominantly negative, with frustration and dissatisfaction being the dominant emotions. Users were particularly critical of the perceived decline in quality, poor support, and lack of transparency from Anthropic.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter noted that A/B testing might explain the inconsistent performance, suggesting that high-usage users could be targeted for testing.
  • ‚Ä¢ Another user highlighted the challenges of fixing bugs in AI-written codebases, emphasizing the need for better testing and modularization.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters speculated that the financial pressures of scaling and profitability might be driving decisions that negatively impact user experience.
  • ‚Ä¢ A recurring theme was the idea of "vibe coding," where rapid development and reliance on AI lead to unstable and poorly maintained software.
  • 5. **Conclusion**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion reflects growing user frustration with Claude Opus 4.5 and Claude Code, particularly regarding reliability, usability, and support. While some users acknowledged the benefits of LLMs, the majority expressed concerns about their limitations and the broader implications of current business practices in the AI industry.
Nobody likes lag: How to make low-latency dev sandboxes
‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.compyle.ai/blog/nobody-likes-lag/
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46735139
‚Ä¢ Score: 89
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Compyle revamped its architecture to eliminate lag in remote coding environments, reducing terminal roundtrip latency from over 200ms to just 14ms by cutting out socket servers and placing sandboxes closer to users.
  • ‚Ä¢ Key upgrades include a warm pool for instant sandbox startup (from 30s to 50ms) and multi-regional pools across the US, Europe, and Asia, ensuring users access the nearest data center for optimal speed.
  • ‚Ä¢ Leveraging fly.io's infrastructure and innovative proxying mechanisms like fly replay streamlined routing, reduced complexity, and significantly boosted performance.
  • #TechInnovation #CloudComputing #DeveloperTools

Discussion Highlights:

  • ‚Ä¢ **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • 1. **Cold Start Latency in Cloud Services**: Several commenters discussed the performance of Google Cloud Run and Cloud Functions v2 compared to AWS Lambda, particularly in terms of cold start latency. AWS Lambda's use of Firecracker was highlighted for achieving sub-second startup times, while GCP options were noted to have longer startup delays.
  • 2. **Sandboxing and Routing Optimization**: A recurring theme was the need for efficient sandboxing solutions, particularly in the context of coding agents and latency reduction. Commenters shared strategies like encoding routing logic into hostnames to eliminate database lookups and using tools like Pingora for improved connection lifecycle control.
  • 3. **Cost vs. Performance Trade-offs**: Several comments addressed the balance between optimizing latency and managing costs, such as shallow warm pools, memory snapshots, and multi-region setups. The economics of maintaining idle capacity were also discussed.
  • 4. **The Rise of Sandboxing Tools**: There was debate about the recent surge in sandbox-related tools and posts, attributed to the growing demand for coding agents and the need for "YOLO mode" execution. Some commenters questioned the necessity of SaaS sandboxes when local resources could suffice.
  • 5. **Developer Frustrations with Remote Infrastructure**: Frustrations were expressed about the complexity and inefficiency of modern development workflows, with some advocating for local development environments over cloud-based solutions.
  • 6. **Specific Tools and Recommendations**: Various tools like Fly.io's sprites.dev, Mosh, and Pingora were discussed, with mixed opinions on their readiness and applicability to different use cases.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Significant Agreements/Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ There was general agreement on the importance of reducing latency and optimizing sandboxing, but differing opinions on whether cloud-based or local solutions are more practical.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters expressed skepticism about the necessity of complex cloud setups for development, while others emphasized the value of distributed infrastructure for specific use cases.
  • ‚Ä¢ The debate over SaaS sandboxes highlighted a divide between those who value their convenience and those who see them as unnecessary compared to leveraging local hardware.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Encoding routing logic into hostnames to eliminate database lookups was a notable optimization shared by a commenter.
  • ‚Ä¢ Fly.io's sprites.dev was mentioned as an emerging tool with innovative features like progressive checkpointing, though it was deemed immature for some use cases.
  • ‚Ä¢ A commenter highlighted the inefficiency of sending excessive network packets per keystroke, emphasizing the need for more streamlined approaches.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Overall Sentiment**:
  • The discussion was a mix of constructive technical insights and critical commentary. While many commenters shared practical solutions and recommendations, there was a notable undercurrent of frustration with the inefficiencies and perceived over-engineering of modern development workflows. The tone was largely analytical, with some humor and sarcasm interspersed.
  • ‚Ä¢ **Noteworthy Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The mention of Pingora and its advantages over NGINX for connection lifecycle control.
  • ‚Ä¢ The critique of Fly.io's sprites.dev for lacking certain features but being promising for new projects.
  • ‚Ä¢ The suggestion to reduce middleware and routing layers to improve latency, resonating with several participants.
What Will You Do When AI runs Out of Money and Disappear?
‚Ä¢ Article: https://louwrentius.com/what-will-you-do-when-ai-will-run-out-of-money-and-disappear.html
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730995
‚Ä¢ Score: 48
‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Major AI services like ChatGPT and Claude are heavily subsidized, with no clear path to profitability due to exorbitant operational costs. Experts predict these services may shut down or become prohibitively expensive.
  • ‚Ä¢ Open-source models and smaller AI players could fill the gap, but they face the same cost challenges, making large-scale AI operations financially unviable without subsidies.
  • ‚Ä¢ Self-hosting AI systems is also cost-prohibitive, and rising demand for hardware could further inflate expenses. A potential scenario involves government intervention to subsidize AI services to maintain accessibility.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics of Discussion**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The cost and sustainability of AI, particularly the expenses related to inference versus training.
  • ‚Ä¢ The viability of self-hosting AI models and the associated hardware costs.
  • ‚Ä¢ The potential evolution of AI technology, hardware, and efficiency over time.
  • ‚Ä¢ Speculation about the AI industry's profitability and future business models.
  • ‚Ä¢ The potential impact of an AI market crash on hardware prices and accessibility.
  • 2. **Key Points**:
  • ‚Ä¢ There is debate about whether inference costs are heavily subsidized or genuinely profitable. Some commenters cite Sam Altman‚Äôs claim that OpenAI is profitable on inference, while others question whether current prices are propped up by investor capital.
  • ‚Ä¢ Open-source AI models and smaller providers offer significantly lower costs for inference compared to major players, suggesting AI could remain accessible even if larger companies struggle.
  • ‚Ä¢ Self-hosting AI is increasingly feasible, with some commenters sharing personal experiences of running models on consumer-grade or older hardware. This indicates that AI could become more decentralized and cost-effective over time.
  • ‚Ä¢ Hardware advancements and optimizations, such as inferencing-specific chips and kv cache, are expected to make AI more efficient and affordable in the future.
  • ‚Ä¢ There is skepticism about the long-term valuations of AI companies, with some predicting a market correction but maintaining that AI technology itself is here to stay.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Many agree that AI is unlikely to disappear even if the current market bubble bursts, drawing parallels to the dot-com bubble.
  • ‚Ä¢ There is disagreement on the current and future costs of hosting AI, with some arguing that self-hosting is viable and others emphasizing the high upfront and operational costs.
  • ‚Ä¢ Commenters differ on whether AI will become cheaper or remain expensive, with some predicting hardware price drops after a potential market crash and others emphasizing the ongoing costs of running AI at scale.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment is mixed but leans towards cautious optimism. While some express concerns about the sustainability of current AI business models and costs, there is a shared belief that AI technology will continue to evolve and become more accessible over time.
  • 5. **Notable Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The idea that AI is still in its early stages, likened to the "coach-built" phase of automobiles, with significant room for efficiency and cost improvements.
  • ‚Ä¢ The notion that AI‚Äôs value proposition may shift over time, with companies focusing on niche applications or reducing reliance on training new models.
  • ‚Ä¢ A humorous but critical observation that AI's profitability might ultimately rely on ads, encapsulated in the phrase "AGI = Ads Generate Income.
  • 6. **Miscellaneous Observations**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters express frustration with the current state of AI, particularly its use in customer service and its perceived impact on creativity.
  • ‚Ä¢ There is a sense of nostalgia and skepticism among older participants, with one commenter lamenting the replacement of natural talent by AI in creative fields.
Show HN: First Claude Code client for Ollama local models

‚Ä¢ Score: 44
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The discussion revolves around the integration and functionality of Anthropic's Claude Code with local models, particularly through llama.cpp and related tools.
  • ‚Ä¢ Several commenters highlight that this capability has been available for months using llama.cpp, with some sharing specific configurations and troubleshooting tips.
  • ‚Ä¢ There is interest in proxies that can translate between OpenAI-style models and Anthropic endpoints, with some users sharing their experiences and challenges in finding reliable solutions.
  • ‚Ä¢ Hardware requirements for running large models like the 30B model are discussed, with a focus on VRAM needs and performance considerations.
  • 2. **Key Points and Insights**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Users note that llama.cpp already supports the Anthropic API, and configurations such as setting the `ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL` and other environment variables are key to making it work.
  • ‚Ä¢ One commenter shares a guide to using Claude Code with local models, highlighting a specific issue with telemetry pings that required disabling non-essential traffic.
  • ‚Ä¢ Proxies for bridging Anthropic and OpenAI-style models are discussed, but there is frustration over incomplete or unreliable implementations.
  • ‚Ä¢ Hardware discussions suggest that running 30B models requires at least 24GB of VRAM for decent performance, with some users sharing their setups and experiences.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • ‚Ä¢ There is general agreement that integrating Claude Code with local models has been possible for some time, but users differ on the ease of setup and reliability of certain tools.
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters express frustration with the complexity of configurations and the lack of fully functional proxies for specific use cases.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • ‚Ä¢ The sentiment is mixed, with users appreciating the availability of tools and guides but also expressing frustration over setup challenges, hardware requirements, and incomplete solutions.
  • 5. **Notable Contributions**:
  • ‚Ä¢ A user shares a detailed guide to using Claude Code with local models, which includes troubleshooting tips and specific configurations.
  • ‚Ä¢ Another user provides a workaround for bypassing onboarding issues with Claude Code by modifying a configuration file.
  • 6. **Additional Observations**:
  • ‚Ä¢ Some commenters point out that other tools, such as Goose and OpenCode, have also enabled similar functionality for some time.
  • ‚Ä¢ A GitHub link for further resources was shared, and a correction was made to a URL in the discussion.
Autodesk burns the village to feed AI and the Cloud ‚Äì cuts 7% of workforce
‚Ä¢ Article: https://blog.adafruit.com/2026/01/22/autodesk-burns-the-village-to-feed-ai-and-the-cloud-cuts-7-of-workforce/
‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46728385
‚Ä¢ Score: 42
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion centers around widespread dissatisfaction with Autodesk, particularly its business practices and software offerings. Many commenters describe the company as monopolistic, anti-consumer, and focused on profit over product quality.
  • 2. Several commenters criticize Autodesk's dominance in architectural, CAD, and BIM software markets, noting that vendor lock-in forces users to rely on its products despite high costs and poor quality. Some compare Autodesk unfavorably to competitors like Blender and Houdini in the 3D graphics space, which are gaining traction due to community support and innovation.
  • 3. There is agreement that Autodesk's acquisition of Revit has contributed to its monopoly in architecture software, enabling it to charge high prices. Some express frustration with the lack of viable open-source alternatives that match Autodesk's feature set.
  • 4. A thread explores the relationship between Autodesk's practices and Wall Street's approval. Commenters explain that Wall Street prioritizes short-term profits, favoring cost-cutting and margin-raising strategies, even if they lead to "enshittification" of products. Vendor lock-in is identified as a key factor that sustains Autodesk's profitability despite user dissatisfaction.
  • 5. While most comments are critical, one commenter shares a positive experience with Autodesk's Fusion 360, citing its affordability and functionality for beginners. However, this perspective is overshadowed by broader concerns about the company's practices.
  • 6. Unique insights include efforts to revive open-source alternatives like LibreDWG and the observation that Wall Street's incentives often conflict with long-term product quality and customer satisfaction.
  • 7. Overall sentiment is overwhelmingly negative, with Autodesk portrayed as a company that prioritizes profits over users, leveraging monopolistic practices and vendor lock-in to maintain dominance.

item.title: Weekend: OpenAI‚Äôs Chaos Energy
item.description:
The Weekend
Welcome, Weekenders! In this newsletter: ‚Ä¢ The Big Read: How Greg and Anna Brockman became MAGA‚Äôs newest megadonors¬† ‚Ä¢ The Takeway: When a Davos trip presents a chance to test AI‚Äôs limits¬†
Jan 24, 2026
Supported by
Welcome, Weekenders! In this newsletter:
‚Ä¢ The Big Read: How Greg and Anna Brockman became MAGA‚Äôs newest megadonors¬†
‚Ä¢ The Takeway: When a Davos trip presents a chance to test AI‚Äôs limits¬†
‚Ä¢ The Top 5: The moguls went to Davos‚Äîthen we went shopping¬†
‚Ä¢ Plus, Recommendations‚Äîour weekly pop culture picks: ‚ÄúArticles of Interest,‚Äù ‚ÄúI Deliver Parcels in Beijing‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Night Manager‚Äù
¬†
In its life so far, OpenAI has accomplished any number of feats, including the releases of ChatGPT, Dall-E and Sora. Those tools, which craft words, pictures and videos with AI, have catalyzed an unprecedented boom time.
Those breakthroughs cast a radiant glow on OpenAI, and steadily, it collected more money faster than any startup ever from everyone who matters in Silicon Valley‚Äînever mind that some of its products flout both copyright law and good taste in nearly equal measure. And never mind that OpenAI‚Äôs board once spontaneously fired (and quickly rehired) its wunderkind CEO, an event that internally has been rebranded as ‚ÄúThe Blip.‚Äù (I kid you not‚Äîthat‚Äôs according to our star AI reporter, Stephanie Palazzolo.)¬†
For the better part of three years, OpenAI enjoyed an enviable perception of itself. The startup‚Äôs rise seemed both predestined and inextinguishable.¬†
Recently, though, the grand narrative about OpenAI has slipped out of the company‚Äôs hands, and its continued dominance no longer seems assured. For a good moment, I found this turn of events surprising. Later, I had to laugh at myself for falling for an OpenAI ploy, which I‚Äôve come to consider the company‚Äôs actual greatest achievement to date: In retrospect, it‚Äôs astounding that it managed to convince a lot of people of its invincibility while a pile of evidence mounted showing that it runs on a stream of chaotic energy. On a list of reliable fuels, such a power source would rank near Iranian-refined plutonium.
I detected a strong sense of that volatility as I edited this week‚Äôs Big Read, which is about OpenAI co-founder Greg Brockman and his wife, Anna. Mostly, the piece delves into their foray into MAGA land and national politics. And there alone, I sense a good amount of chaos: Brockman, apparently, hasn‚Äôt ever held any strong political beliefs, and the donations mostly seem like an opportunistic bid to win favor with President Donald Trump, a fella as swayable as a weathervane in gale-force wind. So who knows what Brockman‚Äôs money will actually get him and what exactly it may cost him in the long run?
Our story does a good job of filling in the rest of the picture around the couple. Some of those details I must‚Äôve known at one point but have since forgotten, like the fact that OpenAI has 11 co-founders. Eleven! Think of that chaos. I have a group chat with my friends that‚Äôs about the same size, and often we‚Äôre lucky if we can reach consensus on whether to arrive for brunch at 12:30 or 1. God forbid we try to arrive together on a definition of what constitutes humanlike AI.
Most of those 11 have left: Brockman and just two other co-founders still remain at OpenAI. I totally get why the others decamped. Chaos can get tiring. I‚Äôm very used to making brunch plans for 12 and eventually sitting down at a table for four. As Brockman has stayed, he and OpenAI have weathered plenty of internal strife. In 2024, for example, OpenAI and Brockman agreed he should take a sabbatical; there‚Äôd been complaints about his workplace combativeness. Three months later, he returned‚Äîshortly after another key executive, Mira Murati, left to begin a rival AI startup, Thinking Machines Lab. Chaos!¬†
In the last few days, OpenAI has grasped to retake control of its story. Shortly, it plans to launch ads, which might offer the same type of energy jolt you get from a mouthful of 6-milligram Zyns, and it has installed a new leader to shape the products it will sell to businesses. Meanwhile on X, one executive was complaining about a ‚Äúnarrative violation‚Äù‚Äîa corporate dog whistle meant to suggest unfair media coverage‚Äîregarding the company‚Äôs recent growth figures.
Will OpenAI recapture its former status quo? I‚Äôd like to think we‚Äôve seen enough stories like our Big Read to make us all at least a liiittle bit more skeptical. Then again, all those Sora videos have left reality feeling rather permanently warped.¬†
What else from this week‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢ If even a portion of Jared Kushner‚Äôs master plan for redeveloping Gaza happens, I somehow anticipate writing future profiles of Kushner family heirs that attribute their wealth to Mediterranean-front condominiums.¬†
‚Ä¢ Om Malik, intrepid chronicler of several past tech eras, casts a weary eye on the realities of today: ‚ÄúIn a system tuned for speed, authority is ornamental.‚Äù
‚Ä¢ Franken-milk, moon landings‚Äîand the 21 other reasons why Wired thinks this century already belongs to China. (According to The New York Times, Donald Trump‚Äôs speech at Davos might qualify as yet another.)
‚Ä¢ Greenoaks Capital and Altimeter Capital are suing the South Korean government over its treatment of Coupang, a Korean e-commerce giant that counts both firms as investors. (Here‚Äôs more on what Greenoaks normally gets up to.)¬†
‚Ä¢ AI‚Äôs effects across the labor market aren‚Äôt very clear at all. That said, it seems pretty indisputable that it has rapidly altered the hunt for the entry-level job.
‚Ä¢ A new trailer for the fifth season of ‚ÄúFor All Mankind‚Äù has dropped. Elsewhere in Hollywood, Riz Ahmed‚Äôs dark comedy series about an actor who tries to get cast as James Bond, ‚ÄúBait,‚Äù may just be the most enjoyable piece of Bond content in years.
‚Ä¢ America wants ‚Äúto break up with the calorie,‚Äù the Times repo‚Äîand dammit, I‚Äôve just crumbled a cookies-and-cream protein bar all over my keyboard.¬†
‚Ä¢ Vintage watch collecting has gotten cool and vibey, says The Economist‚Äîand just a touch problematic for some buyers. ‚ÄúReally, we‚Äôre addicts,‚Äù one collector admits. ‚ÄúJust instead of being addicted to alcohol or cigarettes or drugs, we‚Äôre addicted to the chase of acquiring a new watch.‚Äù‚ÄîAbram Brown

A message from Resource Advisor+

Why Smart Companies Are Consolidating Their Sustainability Software Stack

The tools aren't the problem. The fragmentation between them is. When energy data lives in one place, carbon in another, and supply chain in a third, you can't see the risk ‚Äî you can only react to it. Resource Advisor+ unifies the stack with AI that actually understands your business.

Discover now.

Weekend‚Äôs Latest Stories

The Big Read¬†

How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors
I‚Äôve already talked up this report from our Jemima McEvoy, Stephanie Palazzolo and Sylvia Varnham O‚ÄôRegan quite a bit, so I will only add that it is a compelling reflection of what happens when Silicon Valley realizes Washington is up for sale like never before.¬†

The Takeaway

What AI Missed About My Davos Reporting Trip
Our Jessica Lessin, The Information‚Äôs founder and editor in chief, had a very busy past few days in Davos, Switzerland, the annual power conclave that attracts enough politicos and moguls to fill a mountainside of chalets. AI was the talk of that town this year, and as Jessica began thinking about everything she‚Äôd learned from cruising around those snowy corridors of power, she found an opportunity to experiment with a buzzy piece of AI: Anthropic‚Äôs Claude Cowork.

The Top Five

A Tech Mogul‚Äôs Guide to Winter Fashion, Davos-Style
To do right by Davos, the masters of the universe go dressed to impress. Esther Achara, a returning contributor to Weekend and a veteran of places like Vogue and Glamour, has scrutinized what everyone had on and used it to inspire for some shoppable advice on what to buy this season. As Esther firmly instructs in her piece: Cold and chic can find a warm embrace.¬†
Abram Brown is the editor of The Information's Weekend section. You can reach him at abe@theinformation.com or find him on X.
¬†
Listening: ‚ÄúArticles of Interest‚Äù
Avery Trufelman, host of ‚ÄúArticles of Interest,‚Äù manages to pull off the type of cross-genre reporting vanishingly few journalists can actually do. ‚ÄúArticles of Interest‚Äù is ostensibly a podcast about clothes, but¬† really, it‚Äôs an incisive examination of business, culture, history and fashion, so even if you don‚Äôt know the essential difference between a blazer and a suit coat‚Äîcheck the jacket‚Äôs pockets‚Äîyou‚Äôll find the pod enlightening. The latest season, which is the show‚Äôs seventh, looks at how what the military wears has such deep connections with what we civvies typically choose. (I write this on a day on which I donned a vintage field jacket, a crisp white T-shirt and a denim work shirt.) It‚Äôs the type of show that quietly gets you to look around and notice details about everyday life that might‚Äôve otherwise gone unnoticed.‚ÄîAbram Brown
Reading: ‚ÄúI Deliver Parcels in Beijing‚Äù by Hu Anyan
Over 19 tumultuous years within China, Hu Anyan lived as a modern-day nomad, lurching from job to job‚Äî19 of them, in fact. Nominally, Hu had studied home-appliance repair and advertising design, but neither background helped him win long-lasting employment: Sometimes the jobs evaporated, and sometimes he would just quit and move on, choosing to exist on the edges of society within a rapidly modernizing China.¬†
After time as a gas station attendant and a baker‚Äôs helper, Hu sold women‚Äôs clothes and car accessories online, achieving only limited sales as he tried to understand the various strategies for operating on the country‚Äôs various e-commerce sites. (‚ÄúEven with data, spending money is an art,‚Äù writes Hu. ‚ÄúIt requires a certain technique, or else you risk it going down the drain.‚Äù) Later, he worked in a logistics warehouse and delivered packages. Somehow, Hu found time to read widely‚Äîeveryone from Hemingway to Capote to Joyce‚Äîand to journal often. Some of those reflections became a viral blog post during the pandemic, and in 2023, he published ‚ÄúI Deliver Parcels in Beijing‚Äù in China, where it has been quite popular. A few months ago, he released an English translation.
These days, Hu‚Äôs native land often looms as an enigmatic bogeyman of a country in Western minds. Anyone after greater insight into the place would find ‚ÄúI Deliver Parcels in Beijing‚Äù enriching. (Consider it a fine double feature with Dan Wang‚Äôs ‚ÄúBreakneck,‚Äù a monograph on American and Chinese innovation, which I previously recommended.) With spare prose, Hu presents rich observations on the China around him, shedding some real light on the nation‚Äôs internet economy and his countrymen‚Äôs toilsome approach to their jobs. ‚ÄúWork for the sole purpose of making a living is a miserable prison,‚Äù he writes, ‚Äúwhich is why very few people will confess that this is what they do.‚Äù‚ÄîA.B.
Watching: ‚ÄúThe Night Manager‚Äù¬†
Spies rarely age with enormous amounts of grace‚Äîat least when it comes to the fictional ones, though I expect it‚Äôs much the same for the real-life ones. The latest example is Jonathan Pine (Tom Hiddleston), titular protagonist of the BBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Night Manager,‚Äù which has its long-awaited second season streaming on Amazon Prime. Pine, a former soldier turned‚Äîyes‚Äîhotel manager turned reluctant MI6 recruit, is ridden by clenched-jaw anxiety and plagued by flashbacks to season one‚Äôs violent events. It worries his agency-appointed therapist. ‚ÄúYou frighten me,‚Äù she tells him. (Yikes! Never what a person wants to hear from their shrink.)¬†
The debut season took its plot from the show‚Äôs John le Carr√© source novel, and in an original adventure for this latest outing, Pine finds himself trying to solve his dead boss‚Äôs (Douglas Hodge) murder and stymie the suave Teddy Dos Santos (Diego Calva), an arms dealer. The story has some ties to the previous season and makes sure to carry on the tradition of picking a pretty place‚Äîthis time, it‚Äôs mountainous, sun-drenched Colombia‚Äîand filling it with plenty of attractive people. (Along with Hiddleston and Calva, former model Camila Morrone plays Roxana Bola√±os, a shipping broker.) Safe to say, no one on television has looked as resplendent in linen since Tom Ripley ransacked Dickie‚Äôs closet.‚ÄîA.B.
