item.title: The New MAGA Megadonors: OpenAI's Greg Brockman and His Wife Anna
item.description:
How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors
In November, Greg Brockman, OpenAI‚Äôs president and co-founder, and his wife, Anna, enjoyed a glitzy night out in Washington: a White House state dinner for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The Brockmans were among a broad contingent of tech elite in attendance at the fete, hosted by President Donald Trump. Soon after the event, the Brockmans¬†posted pictures¬†of themselves posing with Elon Musk, Nvidia‚Äôs Jensen Huang and his wife, Lori, and David Sacks, the venture capitalist who‚Äôs become Trump‚Äôs AI and crypto czar. It wasn‚Äôt the only time in the last few months that the Silicon Valley couple has made splashy appearances in Trump‚Äôs orbit. In the fall, they attended two other White House suppers and went to Trump‚Äôs revamped Kennedy Center Honors, dining later that evening with one of the honorees, actor Sylvester Stallone. But nothing has more loudly announced their arrival as Trump-friendly figures than their decision to become megadonors: giving $50 million to Leading the Future, a bipartisan super PAC focused on combating state-level AI regulation, and $25 million to MAGA Inc., a Trump super PAC.
Jan 23, 2026

The Big Read

How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors

By Jemima McEvoy, Stephanie Palazzolo, and Sylvia Varnham O'Regan

In November, Greg Brockman, OpenAI‚Äôs president and co-founder, and his wife, Anna, enjoyed a glitzy night out in Washington: a White House state dinner for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

The Brockmans were among a broad contingent of tech elite in attendance at the fete, hosted by President Donald Trump. Soon after the event, the Brockmans posted pictures of themselves posing with Elon Musk, Nvidia‚Äôs Jensen Huang and his wife, Lori, and David Sacks, the venture capitalist who‚Äôs become Trump‚Äôs AI and crypto czar.

It wasn‚Äôt the only time in the last few months that the Silicon Valley couple has made splashy appearances in Trump‚Äôs orbit. In the fall, they attended two other White House suppers and went to Trump‚Äôs revamped Kennedy Center Honors, dining later that evening with one of the honorees, actor Sylvester Stallone. But nothing has more loudly announced their arrival as Trump-friendly figures than their decision to become megadonors: giving $50 million to Leading the Future, a bipartisan super PAC focused on combating state-level AI regulation, and $25 million to MAGA Inc., a Trump super PAC.

Read the full article

item.title: Major Crypto Exchanges Are Racing to Offer U.S. Stocks
item.description:
Crypto Exchanges Want to Trade U.S. Stocks Everywhere
Some of the world‚Äôs biggest crypto exchanges are racing to let their customers trade crypto tokens that seek to track U.S. stocks, creating a parallel market that‚Äôs beyond the reach of U.S. regulators. Binance is exploring reintroducing stock tokens on its exchange after having removed them in 2021, according to a person familiar with the plan. OKX, another major global platform, is also considering offering tokenized stocks, according to its global managing partner and chief marketing officer, Haider Rafique. Exchanges including Kraken and Bitget and decentralized platforms like Jupiter are already gaining traction with their stock token offerings.
Jan 23, 2026

Exclusive

Crypto Exchanges Want to Trade U.S. Stocks Everywhere

By Yueqi Yang

Some of the world‚Äôs biggest crypto exchanges are racing to let their customers trade crypto tokens that seek to track U.S. stocks, creating a parallel market that‚Äôs beyond the reach of U.S. regulators.

Binance is exploring reintroducing stock tokens on its exchange after having removed them in 2021, according to a person familiar with the plan. OKX, another major global platform, is also considering offering tokenized stocks, according to its global managing partner and chief marketing officer, Haider Rafique. Exchanges including Kraken and Bitget and decentralized platforms like Jupiter are already gaining traction with their stock token offerings.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Overseas crypto exchanges offer U.S. stock tokens, bypassing U.S. regulations.
  • Tokenized stock market value reached $915 million, up 19% monthly.
  • NYSE and Nasdaq plan to offer stock tokens, seeking regulatory approval.

item.title: I Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.
item.description:
How 13 AI agents reviewing in parallel caught a critical bug I would have otherwise missed ¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå¬†‚Äå

Source Code

I Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.

How 13 AI agents reviewing in parallel caught a critical bug I would have otherwise missed

by Kieran Klaassen

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

The bug report was deceptively simple: A user noticed that their email signature formatting was off in Cora, our AI-powered email assistant. I asked Claude Code to investigate and fix it. By morning, the fix had touched 27 files, and more than 1,000 lines of code had changed. I didn‚Äôt write any of them.

A year ago, I would have spent my afternoon reading that code. Line by line, file by file, squinting at the migration that moved email_signature from one database table to another, Ctrl+F-ing for every instance of our feature flags.

This time, I spent 15 minutes making decisions, and the code shipped without a single bug.

Before AI, code review meant reading every line a teammate wrote. You checked for typos, logic errors, and style inconsistencies, the way an editor reviews a manuscript. Now my code reviews no longer involve reading code. And I‚Äôve gotten better at catching problems because of it.

This is code review done the compound engineering way: Agents review in parallel, findings become decisions, and every correction teaches the system what to catch next time. The signature fix that touched 27 files? Thirteen specialized AI reviewers examined it simultaneously while I made dinner.

I‚Äôll show you how I set it up, how it caught a critical bug I would have missed, and how you can start‚Äîeven without custom tooling.

The death of manual code review

Reading code, even briefly, gave me a sense of the shape of things. I could feel when the codebase was getting too complicated. By letting go of manual review, I worried that I‚Äôd lose that clarity, and the architecture would wander off without me.

But I realized, too, that manual code reviews were no longer sustainable. When a developer writes 200 lines, their manager might spend 20 to 40 minutes reading it. The ratio of time spent writing code to reviewing it holds at 5:1 or 10:1‚ÄîI can sit down with a cup of coffee, and the coffee will still be warm by the time I finish. AI has broken that ratio. The time it takes to generate code has collapsed, but the time it takes for a human to review code hasn‚Äôt. Something had to give.

The shift from manual review happened slowly. When Claude Code enacted a set of fixes, I‚Äôd ask it questions, then read the diff (the line-by-line comparison showing what had changed). When I was satisfied, I‚Äôd hold my breath and merge the changes into the main codebase.

Nothing broke. The code was fine. It turned out that asking Claude to explain its reasoning‚Äîwhat it changed, why, and what might break‚Äîcaught more than my tired eyes scrolling through diffs.

After a while, that close read turned into a quick skim. The skim turned into a glance. Eventually I found that by the time I had asked my questions, I‚Äôd already hit ‚Äúmerge.‚Äù

I still understood how good the code was‚Äîthat clarity just came in a different way. Instead of feeling the shape of the code by reading it, I felt it by interrogating Claude Code:

  1. ‚ÄúWalk me through what you changed and why.‚Äù
  2. ‚ÄúWhat assumptions did you make?‚Äù
  3. ‚ÄúWhat would break this?‚Äù
  4. ‚ÄúWhy did you ignore the feedback from kieran-reviewer?‚Äù

That last one needs explaining. kieran-reviewer is an AI agent I built‚Äîa specialized reviewer trained on my code preferences. It knows, for instance, that I prefer simple queries over complex queries and clear code over clever code. It‚Äôs one of 13 reviewers that examine every pull request before I see it.

Why so many agents? No single reviewer, human or AI, catches everything in a 27-file change. A security expert spots authentication gaps but misses database issues. A performance specialist catches slow queries but ignores style drift. I needed specialists working in parallel, each focused on what they‚Äôre good at. Together, they catch what I might miss from a manual review.

Write at the speed of thought

That gap between your brain and your fingers kills momentum. Monologue lets you speak naturally and get perfect text 3x faster, and your tone, vocabulary, and style is kept intact. It auto-learns proper nouns, handles multilingual code-switching mid-sentence, and edits for accuracy. Free 1,000 words to start.

Download Monologue for Mac
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

Using the compound engineering plugin

My system for code review is rolled up into the compound engineering plugin. It‚Äôs a set of files in your codebase that extend what Claude Code can do. Here‚Äôs how it works.

Slash commands are shortcuts you type in the terminal‚Äîlike /workflows:review or /workflows:plan‚Äîthat trigger workflows. Each workflow is a markdown file with instructions for what Claude should do when you invoke it.

Agents are specialized AI workers, each defined in its own markdown file with a persona and focus area.

For the email signature fix, I ran a single command: /workflows:review, which spun up every agent on its list at once:

  1. kieran-rails-reviewer checks my personal style preferences
  2. code-simplicity-reviewer hunts for over-engineering
  3. data-integrity-guardian validates database changes during migrations (when the structure of your database changes)
  4. security-sentinel checks for authentication bypasses
  5. Plus nine more, each with a specific focus

Ten minutes later, they returned with findings ranked by priority.

From findings to decisions

The agents produce findings. But a list of issues isn‚Äôt useful‚ÄîI need to know what to do about them. So I run the next command: /triage

Triage takes all 13 reviewers‚Äô findings, ranks them by severity, and walks me through each one. It presents every finding in the same way: Here‚Äôs the problem, here‚Äôs why it matters, now what do you want to do?


I can accept the recommendation (and the system creates a task to fix it), skip it (it‚Äôs not worth addressing), or provide specific instructions.

The signature fix surfaced three findings. The first was critical: The code had moved where we store a user setting, but one file still looked for it in the old location. If I‚Äôd shipped this, every user who tried to generate a draft response would have hit an error. The fix itself is trivial‚Äîpoint the code at the new location‚Äîbut I never would have caught it scrolling through diffs.

The second was cleanup. A chunk of unused code, left over from an earlier approach. It wasn‚Äôt broken, but it was confusing. On the chance that someone did read the code in the future, they would wonder what it was for. I approved this change too.

The third was a nitpick‚Äîa minor redundancy, technically true but harmless. I skipped it. I‚Äôll clean it up next time I‚Äôm in that file.

I got three findings and made three decisions in less than two minutes.

The critical finding alone justified the review. I never would have caught a mismatched reference on line 31 while scrolling through 1,000 lines at 6 p.m. The agents caught it in seconds.

The fix is never the last fix

The signature fix should have been simple. I‚Äôd make one change and be done. But sometimes when you fix a piece of code, you end up breaking another. This is just as true with human developers as with coding agents.

In our case, the first version fixed the signature formatting in Gmail, but it broke the plain text version of emails. Some email apps don‚Äôt display styled text, and now those users saw raw formatting codes instead of readable text.

So we fixed that. But the fix for plain text created extra blank lines for users who didn‚Äôt have signatures at all.

So I fixed that too. Then we discovered that when you reply to a heavily-styled marketing email, our formatting rules were leaking into the quoted text. Users saw gibberish like #outlook a { padding: 0; } in their message body.

I fixed that. Next we found that Cora was now appending your email signature after each suggested draft of an email, instead of just once at the very end. If you generated three options, you‚Äôd get three signatures. Which called for another fix.

Ten versions of the code. Four bugs we introduced while fixing the original. Hence the 27 files and thousand lines of code. Again, this is a normal part of any development process, human or AI. The difference is that here, we can codify our learnings to make sure we don‚Äôt make the same mistake next time.

The 50/50 rule

I spent 15 minutes fixing those bugs. Then I spent another 15 minutes making sure I‚Äôd never see them again.

After the signature mess, we created a document called refactor-email-content-rendering.md. It lives in our codebase, and it captures everything we learned:

  1. A chart showing every combination of user settings and what should happen in each case, so there would be no more guessing.
  2. A simple rule about which part of the system handles formatting: ‚ÄúThe background process sends styled text. The Gmail connector never converts formats.‚Äù
  3. The exact format Gmail expects for signatures, pulled from actual emails we tested‚Äînot what we assumed, but what we verified.

That document is now part of the project. The next time anyone touches email rendering‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs me, a teammate, or Claude‚Äîthe AI reads it first.

In my first weeks using this workflow, Claude presented me with approaches that weren‚Äôt necessarily wrong, but didn‚Äôt reflect my preferences. What I consider ‚Äúover-engineered,‚Äù another engineer might call ‚Äúrobust.‚Äù What I see as a missed pattern, someone else might not use at all. Three months and 50-plus reviews in, Claude‚Äôs plans largely reflect how I‚Äôd approach problems myself.

Better AI models make everyone‚Äôs output better. But your system gets better because you‚Äôre accumulating your own team‚Äôs knowledge. Your agents learn your preferences, and your review process reveals your blind spots. That‚Äôs where compounding happens.

So follow the 50/50 rule: Spend half your time reviewing output, half ensuring the lesson sticks.

Rethink reviews

Most engineers assume they need to read everything. That assumption made sense when humans wrote all the code. But it doesn‚Äôt anymore.

I shipped the email signature fix without reading most of the code. I reviewed findings and made decisions. I looked at screenshots in Gmail. But did I read the implementation details of how we extract email content? No. Did I trace through how the database change handles edge cases? No.

Yet the feature works. Users get properly formatted signatures. The tests‚Äîchecks I write alongside every feature to verify the code behaves correctly‚Äîall pass. The screenshots look right. It took some time to let go of manual code reviews, but the results speak for themselves.

The trade I‚Äôve made is that I won‚Äôt read every line, but a part of the time I would spend reading code now goes toward making the system smarter. I‚Äôm adding test cases for marketing emails stuffed with weird formatting. I‚Äôm capturing ‚Äúwhen you change where data lives, check every file that reads it‚Äù as a rule the agents enforce automatically. This way, the next person who touches this code‚Äîhuman or AI‚Äîdoesn‚Äôt repeat my mistakes.

If you don‚Äôt have the compound engineering plugin yet, start with three questions. Before you approve any AI-generated output‚Äîcode, documents, or strategy decks‚Äîask the AI:

  1. What was the hardest decision you made here?
  2. What alternatives did you reject, and why?
  3. What are you least confident about?

That conversation, which takes two minutes, surfaces what a 30-minute unfocused manual check would have missed. The AI knows where the tricky parts are. It just doesn‚Äôt volunteer them unless you ask.

Then apply the 50/50 rule. Spend half of your time fixing the immediate problem and half documenting it, making sure the problem never comes back.

The 27 files involved in rendering an email signature are waiting for the next feature. I‚Äôm still not going to read them all. But when I‚Äôm done, the system will know more than it did when I started.

Kieran Klaassen is the general manager of Cora, Every‚Äôs email product. Follow him on X at @kieranklaassen or on LinkedIn.

To read more essays like this, subscribe to Every, and follow us on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

We build AI tools for readers like you. Write brilliantly with Spiral. Organize files automatically with Sparkle. Deliver yourself from email with Cora. Dictate effortlessly with Monologue.

item.title: The math on AI agents doesn‚Äôt add up
item.description:
PLUS: What hallucinations reveal about the future of automation.

View in browser  |  Update preferences 

‚ñ† In this week‚Äôs Backchannel: A research paper suggests AI agents are mathematically doomed to fail. The industry doesn‚Äôt agree.

 

Agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time

The big AI companies promised us that 2025 would be ‚Äúthe year of the AI agents.‚Äù It turned out to be the year of talking about AI agents, and kicking the can for that transformational moment to 2026 or maybe later. But what if the answer to the question ‚ÄúWhen will our lives be fully automated by generative AI robots that perform our tasks for us and basically run the world?‚Äù is, like that New Yorker cartoon, ‚ÄúHow about never?‚Äù

That was basically the message of a paper published without much fanfare some months ago, smack in the middle of the overhyped year of ‚Äúagentic AI.‚Äù Entitled ‚ÄúHallucination Stations: On Some Basic Limitations of Transformer-Based Language Models,‚Äù it purports to mathematically show that ‚ÄúLLMs are incapable of carrying out computational and agentic tasks beyond a certain complexity.‚Äù Though the science is beyond me, the authors‚Äîa former SAP CTO who studied AI under one of the field‚Äôs founding intellects, John McCarthy; and his teenage prodigy son‚Äîpunctured the vision of agentic paradise with the certainty of mathematics. Even reasoning models that go beyond the pure word-prediction process of LLMs, they say, won‚Äôt fix the problem.

‚ÄúThere is no way they can be reliable,‚Äù Vishal Sikka, the dad, tells me. After a career that, in addition to SAP, included a stint as Infosys CEO and an Oracle board member, he currently heads an AI services startup called Vianai. ‚ÄúSo we should forget about AI agents running nuclear power plants?‚Äù I ask. ‚ÄúExactly,‚Äù he says. Maybe you can get it to file some papers or something to save time, but you might have to resign yourself to some mistakes.

The AI industry begs to differ. For one thing, a big success in agent AI has been coding, which took off last year. Just this week at Davos, Google‚Äôs Nobel-winning head of AI, Demis Hassabis, reported breakthroughs in minimizing hallucinations, and hyperscalers and startups alike are pushing the agent narrative. Now they have some backup. A startup called Harmonic is reporting a breakthrough in AI coding that also hinges on mathematics‚Äîand tops benchmarks on reliability.

Harmonic, which was cofounded by Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev and Tudor Achim, a Stanford-trained mathematician, claims this recent improvement to its product called Aristotle (no hubris there!) is an indication that there are ways to guarantee the trustworthiness of AI systems. ‚ÄúAre we doomed to be in a world where AI just generates slop and humans can't really check it? That would be a crazy world,‚Äù says Achim. Harmonic‚Äôs solution is to use formal methods of mathematical reasoning to verify an LLM‚Äôs output. Specifically, it encodes outputs in the Lean programming language, which is known for its ability to verify the coding. To be sure, Harmonic‚Äôs focus to date has been narrow‚Äîits key mission is the pursuit of ‚Äúmathematical superintelligence,‚Äù and coding is a somewhat organic extension. Things like history essays‚Äîwhich can‚Äôt be mathematically verified‚Äîare beyond its boundaries. For now.

Nonetheless, Achim doesn‚Äôt seem to think that reliable agentic behavior is as much an issue as some critics believe. ‚ÄúI would say that most models at this point have the level of pure intelligence required to reason through booking a travel itinerary,‚Äù he says.

Both sides are right‚Äîor maybe even on the same side. On one hand, everyone agrees that hallucinations will continue to be a vexing reality. In a paper published last September, OpenAI scientists wrote, ‚ÄúDespite significant progress, hallucinations continue to plague the field, and are still present in the latest models.‚Äù They proved that unhappy claim by asking three models, including ChatGPT, to provide the title of the lead author‚Äôs dissertation. All three made up fake titles and all misreported the year of publication. In a blog about the paper, OpenAI glumly stated that in AI models, ‚Äúaccuracy will never reach 100 percent.‚Äù

Right now, those inaccuracies are serious enough to discourage the wide adoption of agents in the corporate world. ‚ÄúThe value has not been delivered,‚Äù says Himanshu Tyagi, cofounder of an open source AI company called Sentient. He points out that dealing with hallucinations can disrupt an entire work flow, negating much of the value of an agent.

Yet the big AI powers and many startups believe these inaccuracies can be dealt with. The key to coexisting with hallucinations, they say, is creating guardrails that filter out the imaginative bullshit that LLMs love to produce. Even Sikka thinks that this is a probable outcome. ‚ÄúOur paper is saying that a pure LLM has this inherent limitation‚Äîbut at the same time it is true that you can build components around LLMs that overcome those limitations,‚Äù he says.

Achim, the mathematical verification guy, agrees that hallucinations will always be around‚Äîbut considers this a feature, not a bug. ‚ÄúI think hallucinations are intrinsic to LLMs and also necessary for going beyond human intelligence,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe way that systems learn is by hallucinating something. It‚Äôs often wrong, but sometimes it's something that no human has ever thought before.‚Äù

The bottom line is that like generative AI itself, agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time. There may not be a specific annum that will be looked back upon as ‚Äúthe year of the agent.‚Äù But hallucinations or not, every year from now on is going to be ‚Äúthe year of more agents,‚Äù as the delta between guardrails and hallucinations narrows. The industry has too much at stake not to make this happen. The tasks that agents perform will always require some degree of verification‚Äîand of course people will get sloppy and we‚Äôll suffer small and large disasters‚Äîbut eventually agents will match or surpass the reliability of human beings, while being faster and cheaper.

At that point, some bigger questions arise. One person I contacted to discuss the hallucination paper was computer pioneer Alan Kay, who is friendly with Sikka. His view is that ‚Äútheir argument was posed well enough to get comments from real computational theorists.‚Äù (A statement reminiscent of his 1984 take on the Macintosh as ‚Äúthe first personal computer good enough to be criticized.‚Äù) But ultimately, he says, the mathematical question is beside the point. Instead, he suggests people consider the issue in light of Marshall McLuhan‚Äôs famous ‚ÄúMedium is the message‚Äù dictum. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask whether something is good or bad, right or wrong,‚Äù he paraphrases. ‚ÄúFind out what is going on.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs going on: We may well be on the cusp of a massive automation of human cognitive activity. It‚Äôs an open question whether this will improve the quality of our work and our lives. I suspect that the ultimate assessment of that will not be mathematically verifiable.

Time Travel

I was heartened that Tudor Achim spoke well of hallucinations, because two years ago I wrote ‚ÄúIn Defense of AI Hallucinations,‚Äù a piece that embraced the possibility that AI would never rid itself of its troublesome inaccuracies. Like Achim, I celebrated the creative spirit of AI confabulation. But I also conjectured that as long as chatbots got stuff wrong, we wouldn‚Äôt let them take over the world. I‚Äôm not so sure about the last part anymore.

Santosh Vempala, a computer science professor at Georgia Tech, has also studied hallucinations. ‚ÄúA language model is just a probabilistic model of the world,‚Äù he says, not a truthful mirror of reality. Vempala explains that an LLM‚Äôs answer strives for a general calibration with the real world‚Äîas represented in its training data‚Äîwhich is ‚Äúa weak version of accuracy.‚Äù His research, published with OpenAI‚Äôs Adam Kalai, found that hallucinations are unavoidable for facts that can‚Äôt be verified using the information in a model‚Äôs training data.

That‚Äôs the science/math of AI hallucinations, but they‚Äôre also notable for the experience they can elicit in humans. At times, these generative fabrications can seem more plausible than actual facts, which are often astonishingly bizarre and unsatisfying. How often do you hear something described as so strange that no screenwriter would dare script it in a movie? These days, all the time! Hallucinations can seduce us by appearing to ground us to a world less jarring than the actual one we live in. What‚Äôs more, I find it telling to note just which details the bots tend to concoct. In their desperate attempt to fill in the blanks of a satisfying narrative, they gravitate toward the most statistically likely version of reality as represented in their internet-scale training data, which can be a truth in itself. I liken it to a fiction writer penning a novel inspired by real events. A good author will veer from what actually happened to an imagined scenario that reveals a deeper truth, striving to create something more real than reality.

Ask Me One Question

Alexandra asks, ‚ÄúHow do tech journalists stay curious without getting cynical?"

Thanks for the question, Alexandra. It‚Äôs helpful that you gave a clue as to what you meant by sharing that you are recovering from tech burnout and are worried about returning to that world ‚Äúwithout falling back into the toxic parts.‚Äù So what you are saying is that some of the unattractive aspects of techland‚Äîselfish oligarchs, enshittified products, and the pursuit of progress without sufficient regard for what benefits society‚Äîcan nullify what‚Äôs truly exciting about the field.

I can‚Äôt speak for all tech journalists, but what keeps me from being cynical is a perpetual fascination with the technology itself and the people who lend their creativity and acumen to building breakthrough products and making cutting-edge discoveries. For instance, I found that writing the backstory of the invention of AI transformers was inspiring, fun, and instructive.

And if some of those people turn to the dark side? Hey, that‚Äôs interesting too. Instead of fomenting cynicism, bad behavior on the part of powerful tech people calls for the scrutiny that journalists can and should exercise. Identifying the flaws in our world doesn‚Äôt make us cynical‚Äîbeaming sunshine in dark corners is actually a hopeful act, urging people to do better. Even if fanboys rip us on social media for our work.

Quote of the Week

‚Äú[AI] may go too fast for society ‚Ä¶ Should you do it all at once? No. You will have civil unrest. So phase it in.‚Äù

‚ÄîJPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, speaking at Davos in favor of hitting the brakes on AI.

What did you think about today's newsletter? Let me know by emailing me at backchannel@wired.com

In Other News

  • We Are Witnessing the Self-Immolation of a Superpower With Donald Trump‚Äôs actions in Greenland, Minneapolis, and Venezuela, a foreign enemy could not invent a better chain of events to wreck the standing of the United States.
  • Chinese EV Batteries Are Eating the World China‚Äôs lithium batteries aren‚Äôt always ‚Äúmade in China.‚Äù Companies like BYD and CATL are building factories on nearly every continent.
  • Your First Humanoid Robot Coworker Will Probably Be Chinese Explosive acceleration, limited dexterity, eyes in the back of its head. What could possibly go wrong?

Sign Up to Our Other Subscriber Newsletters

Made in China

A clear-eyed view of the tech news coming out of China by Zeyi Yang and Louise Matsakis
Sign up

AI Lab

Resident AI expert Will Knight takes you to the furthest edges of this fast-changing field
Sign up

 

MORE FROM WIRED.COM

 
 

You‚Äôre receiving this email because you signed up for the BACKCHANNEL newsletter from WIRED.

Manage your preferences  |  View our Privacy Policy  |  Unsubscribe

Have questions or comments? Send us a message.

Need help? Contact us.

  • ‚Ä¢ To address this, the team created a novel test focused less on hardware optimization, successfully stumping current AI models and restoring its ability to identify exceptional human talent.

  • ‚Ä¢ The AI leverages real-time music trends, culture, history, and user listening behavior to curate playlists, offering personalized recommendations or entirely new discoveries, even allowing users to bypass their own listening history.
  • ‚Ä¢ The feature supports creative prompts, such as playlists inspired by moods, weather, or TV shows, and introduces the potential for a new type of creator who designs shareable AI prompts for others to explore.

Article Summary:

  • ‚Ä¢ Neurophos, a photonics startup, has developed a groundbreaking "metasurface modulator" that enables optical processing units (OPUs) to perform matrix vector multiplication faster and more efficiently than traditional silicon-based GPUs, addressing the growing energy demands of AI inference.
  • ‚Ä¢ The startup claims its OPU achieves 235 Peta Operations per Second (POPS) at 56 GHz while consuming just 675 watts, outperforming Nvidia‚Äôs B200 AI GPU by a wide margin in both speed and energy efficiency.
